review.title: A Survey of Word Reordering in Statistical Machine Translation: Computational Models and Language Phenomena
review.abstract: Word reordering is one of the most difficult aspects of statistical machine translation (SMT), and an important factor of its quality and efficiency. Despite the vast amount of research published to date, the interest of the community in this problem has not decreased, and no single method appears to be strongly dominant across language pairs. Instead, the choice of the optimal approach for a new translation task still seems to be mostly driven by empirical trials. To orientate the reader in this vast and complex research area, we present a comprehensive survey of word reordering viewed as a statistical modeling challenge and as a natural language phenomenon. The survey describes in detail how word reordering is modeled within different string-based and tree-based SMT frameworks and as a stand-alone task, including systematic overviews of the literature in advanced reordering modeling. We then question why some approaches are more successful than others in different language pairs. We argue that, besides measuring the amount of reordering, it is important to understand which kinds of reordering occur in a given language pair. To this end, we conduct a qualitative analysis of word reordering phenomena in a diverse sample of language pairs, based on a large collection of linguistic knowledge. Empirical results in the SMT literature are shown to support the hypothesis that a few linguistic facts can be very useful to anticipate the reordering characteristics of a language pair and to select the SMT framework that best suits them.

sections.heading: 2.4 Word Reordering as Pre- (or Post-) Processing
sections.text: Given the complexity of word reordering during the decoding process, a productive line of research has focused on the decoupling of word reordering decisions from translation decisions. These approaches aim to arrange the starting sentence in a targeted order before or after the translation. Thus, word reordering techniques are solved as pre- or post-processing (i.e. pre-ordering or post-ordering approaches as opposed to standard SMTs). Many other pre-ordering strategies have been proposed: Deterministic preordering aims to find an optimal reordering for each input judgment, which is then translated monotonically or with a low distortion limit.

sections.text: The rest of this work is organized as follows: Section 2 describes briefly summarized studies on the reordering problem and other related technologies known as post-editing. Section 3 details the proposed method, using Japanese translation as a test case. Section 4 reports on our experiments and discusses the results. Section 5 concludes this paper with our prospects for future work. Section 3 Related work is both a theoretically and practically challenging problem in SMT. In the early stages of SMT studies, reordering is modeled by distance-based constraints in translation models (Brown et al., 1993; Koehn et al., 2003). This reordering model is simple and also works in language pairs that are relatively similar to French-English. Distance-based reordering of words is not useful in some language pairs such as English-Japanese because they are very different word orders and appropriate reordering of words and phrases highly dependent on their synchronisms.

sections.heading: 3. Evaluating Word Reordering in Statistical Machine Translation
sections.text: There are innumerable ways to accurately represent the meaning of a source sentence in the target language. In general, SMT systems are judged by the extent to which their results resemble a series of reference translations produced by different human translators. Although they rely on a very rough approximation of language variability, this approach provides SMT researchers with fast automatic metrics that can at least partially guide them toward improvement. In addition, rapid evaluation metrics are used to automatically match SMT characteristics to a development corpus, for example, through minimal error rate training procedures (Och 2003). The design of MT evaluation metrics that correlate with human judgement is an active area of research. We briefly have two widely used general metrics, BLEU and METEOR, and then describe in more detail a number of reclassification specific metrics (Papineni et al 2001).

sections.heading: 4. Reordering Phenomena in Natural Languages
sections.text: In order to select and improve the right SMT models, it is essential to understand the complexity of the reordering of words in natural languages (Birch, Osborne and Koehn 2008; Birch, Blunsom and Osborne 2009). While it is certainly important to measure the extent of the reordering of words, it is also essential to understand what types of reordering occur in a particular language pair. To this end, we present a qualitative analysis of the reordering of words based on linguistic knowledge. More specifically, we draw on a large amount of syntactical information gathered by linguists from more than 1500 languages and systematized in the World Atlas of Language Structures (WALS) (Dryer and Haspelmath 2011). Following the pioneering work of linguist Matthew S. Dryer, we describe the word ordering profile of a language based on the canonical ordering of its components (word ordering features).

sections.heading: 4.2 Word order profiles
sections.text: The word order profile of a language is determined by the canonical order of its components (word order characteristics). Generally, the basic or canonical order of a component group can be determined by criteria of frequency (i.e., the most common), distribution (the least restricted use), or pragmatism (the neutral). Although some languages are supposed to have a free (or flexible) order, it is often possible to recognize a dominant and neutral one.
